'''John Anderson''' may refer to:

==Business==
*[[John Anderson (Scottish businessman)]] (1747–1820), Scottish merchant and founder of Fermoy, Ireland
*[[John Byers Anderson]] (1817–1897), American educator, military officer and railroad executive, mentor of Andrew Carnegie
*[[John Macvicar Anderson]] (1835–1915), Scottish architect
*[[John Anderson (publisher)]] (1836–1910), Norwegian-American publisher
*[[John Anderson (merchant)]] (1852–1924), Scottish merchant, of Singapore and Eastcote
*[[John L. Anderson (shipbuilder)]] (1868–1941) Seattle steamboat pioneer and shipbuilder
*[[Sir John Anderson, 1st Baronet, of Harrold Priory]] (1878–1963), Scottish haulage contractor
*[[John E. Anderson]] (1917–2011), American businessman, namesake of the UCLA Anderson School of Management
*[[John Anderson (New Zealand businessman, born 1938)]], New Zealand businessman, founder of Contiki Holidays and professional public speaker
*[[Jock R. Anderson]] (born 1941), Australian agricultural economist
*[[John Anderson (inventor)]] (1942–2012), founder, director and the chief technology officer of HeartSine Technologies
*[[John Anderson (New Zealand businessman, born 1945)]] (1945–2018), chief executive of the ANZ National Bank in New Zealand

'''John David Anderson''' (born December 13, 1954)<ref name=CMT>{{cite web | title=John Anderson bio | url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/anderson_john_1_/bio.jhtml | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040406061724/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/anderson_john_1_/bio.jhtml | url-status=dead | archive-date=April 6, 2004 | publisher=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] | access-date=May 8, 2009}}</ref> is an American [[country music|country]] singer with a successful career that has lasted more than 40 years. Starting in 1977 with the release of his first single, "I've Got a Feelin' (Somebody's Been Stealin')", Anderson has charted more than 40 singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country [[music charts]], including five number ones: "[[Wild and Blue (song)|Wild and Blue]]", "[[Swingin' (John Anderson song)|Swingin']]", "[[Black Sheep (John Anderson song)|Black Sheep]]", "[[Straight Tequila Night]]", and "[[Money in the Bank (John Anderson song)|Money in the Bank]]". He has also recorded 22 studio albums on several labels. His latest album, ''Years'', was released on April 10, 2020, on the Easy Eye Sound label and was produced by Nashville veteran producer [[David R. Ferguson|David Ferguson]] and [[Dan Auerbach]] of [[The Black Keys]].

Anderson was inducted to the [[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]] on October 5, 2014.<ref>[http://www.nashvillesongwritersfoundation.com/2014/nashville-songwriters-hall-of-fame-inducts-john-anderson,-paul-craft,-tom-douglas-and-gretchen-peters-nsai-presents-annual-awards.aspx] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024070704/http://www.nashvillesongwritersfoundation.com/2014/nashville-songwriters-hall-of-fame-inducts-john-anderson%2C-paul-craft%2C-tom-douglas-and-gretchen-peters-nsai-presents-annual-awards.aspx|date=October 24, 2014}}, nashvillesongwritersfoundation.com, October 6, 2014; accessed January 3, 2015.</ref> He was [[List of Country Music Hall of Fame inductees|elected]] into the [[Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum|Country Music Hall of Fame]] ten years later in 2024.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://variety.com/2024/music/news/country-music-hall-fame-toby-keith-john-anderson-james-burton-2024-inductees-1235944666/|title=Toby Keith Elected Into Country Music Hall of Fame, in Voting That Wrapped Up Days Before His Death|first1=Chris|last1=Willman|magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=March 18, 2024}}</ref>

==Early career==
Raised in [[Apopka, Florida]], Anderson's first musical influences were not country artists, but [[rock and roll]] musicians such as [[Jimi Hendrix]] and [[The Rolling Stones]].<ref name=CountryBack>{{cite web | title=John Anderson is Takin' the Country Back... And Who Is Better Qualified | url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1473302/06262003/anderson_john_1_.jhtml | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040505031901/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1473302/06262003/anderson_john_1_.jhtml | url-status=dead | archive-date=May 5, 2004 | publisher=[[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] | date=July 29, 1997 | access-date=May 8, 2009}}</ref> He played in a rock band until the age of 15, when he discovered the music of [[George Jones]] and [[Merle Haggard]] and turned to country music.<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p1503/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=John Anderson biography|last=Huey|first=Steve|work=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=May 18, 2009}}</ref> Anderson moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 1971, arriving unannounced at his sister's home, and took on odd jobs during the day – including one as a [[Roof construction|roofer]] at the [[Grand Ole Opry]] House – while playing in clubs during the evenings.<ref name=Billboard>{{cite web | title=John Anderson bio | url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=john anderson|bio=true}} | publisher=Billboard.com | access-date=May 8, 2009}}</ref>

The club appearances finally paid off in 1977 when he signed his first recording contract with [[Warner Bros. Records]]. He first hit the [[Hot Country Songs|Billboard Country chart]] in 1977 with the song "I've Got a Feelin' (Somebody's Been Stealin')",<ref name=CountryBack/> then broke into the country Top 40 with "The Girl at the End of the Bar" the next year. Anderson's decidedly backwoods accent and distinctive vocal timbre helped land him in the forefront of the "New Traditionalist" movement with artists like [[Ricky Skaggs]] and [[George Strait]].<ref name=CMT/>

A steady stream of singles through the late 1970s and early 1980s continued to build Anderson's name in the country genre. The song "[[I'm Just an Old Chunk of Coal (But I'm Gonna Be a Diamond Someday)]]" from the 1981 album ''[[John Anderson 2]]'' netted Anderson a [[Grammy Award]] nomination for Best Male Country Vocal Performance.<ref>{{cite web | title=John Anderson 2 | url=http://www.johnanderson.com/ja_d_john_anderson_2.html | publisher=johnanderson.com | access-date=May 8, 2009 | url-status=dead | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090401034254/http://www.johnanderson.com/ja_d_john_anderson_2.html | archive-date=April 1, 2009 }}</ref>

=="Swingin'" and mainstream success==

The release of Anderson's fourth album, ''[[Wild & Blue]]'', in 1982 led to his breakthrough to mainstream country when the single "Swingin'" hit the airwaves early the next year. Co-written with long-time writing partner, Lionel Delmore, the song broke into the country charts and reached Number One by March, while at the same time crossing over to the Billboard Hot 100, reaching a peak of Number 43.<ref>{{cite news |title=He's as American as swinging on the porch |work=Kingman Daily Miner |page=11 |date=April 8, 1983 |access-date=May 9, 2009 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NlkLAAAAIBAJ&dq=john-anderson%20swingin&pg=5809%2C4208978 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The single became the biggest selling record in the history of Warner Bros. Records.<ref name=CountryBack/> In the wake of "Swingin'", Anderson received five nominations for [[Country Music Association]] awards for the year. He was the winner of the Horizon Award, and the song was named Single of the Year; he also received nominations for Song of the Year, Male Vocalist of the Year, and Album of the Year.<ref name=CMAAwards>{{cite web | title=CMA Awards: John Anderson | url=http://www.cmaawards.com/2008/database/ArtistDetail.aspx?artistId=131 | publisher=cmaawards.com | access-date=May 8, 2009 }}</ref>

Anderson's success with ''Wild & Blue'' carried on through several more albums, but none would match its chart numbers or sales. In 1986, Anderson and Warner Bros. parted ways.<ref name="allmusic"/>

==''Seminole Wind'' and later career ==

After leaving Warner Bros., Anderson signed with [[MCA Records]] and released two albums under that label, followed by one with [[Capitol Records]] in 1990. Chart success was minimal throughout those years. However, that turned around in 1991 when Anderson joined [[BNA Records]] and, working with legendary country producer [[James Stroud]], released the album ''[[Seminole Wind]]''. Powered by the [[Seminole Wind (song)|title single]], which rose to Number Two, and the Number One single "[[Straight Tequila Night]]", the album proved a resurgence for Anderson's career.<ref name=Heartland>{{cite web | title=Heartland | url=http://www.upi.com/Odd_News/2002/12/06/Heartland-UPI-Arts-Entertainment/UPI-87461039161600/ | publisher=UPI.com | date=December 6, 2002 | access-date=May 9, 2009}}</ref> The album has been certified two times [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]], the highest of any of Anderson's albums, and he was nominated for three CMA Awards – Male Vocalist, Song of the Year and Album of the Year.<ref name=CMAAwards/>

The success of ''Seminole Wind'' brought a fresh life to Anderson's career, and he released a number of albums that charted well, producing several more singles that pushed to the upper levels of the country charts. The 1993 album ''[[Solid Ground (John Anderson album)|Solid Ground]]'' produced a Number One single, "[[Money in the Bank (John Anderson song)|Money in the Bank]]", which turned out to be the most recent chart-topper of Anderson's career. He recorded for BNA through 1996 before leaving the label.<ref name=CMT/> In 1993, Anderson was awarded the [[Academy of Country Music]] Career Achievement award.<ref>{{cite web | title=John Anderson awards | url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/anderson_john_1_/awards.jhtml | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040307074534/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/anderson_john_1_/awards.jhtml | url-status=dead | archive-date=March 7, 2004 | publisher=CMT.com | access-date=May 9, 2009}}</ref>

Anderson has recorded for several labels since his departure from BNA, with moderate chart success.<ref name=Billboard/> An album entitled ''[[Bigger Hands]]'', a return to working with Stroud as producer, was released in June 2009.<ref>{{cite web | title=John Anderson Plans New Album With James Stroud | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1609037/john-anderson-plans-new-album-with-james-stroud.jhtml | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414055201/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1609037/john-anderson-plans-new-album-with-james-stroud.jhtml | url-status=dead | archive-date=April 14, 2009 | work=CMT News | publisher=CMT.com | date=April 10, 2009 | access-date=May 9, 2009}}</ref>

Over his career, Anderson has collaborated with a number of different artists. He worked with [[Waylon Jennings]] on his last ever live album before Jennings's death in 2002, [[Never Say Die: The Final Concert]], where he performed a duet with Jennings on the track Waymore's Blues. He has also worked with [[John Rich (musician)|John Rich]] of [[Big & Rich]] on his 2007 album ''[[Easy Money (album)|Easy Money]]'',<ref name=easymoney>{{cite web | title=Yahoo News | url=http://new.music.yahoo.com/tommy-lee/news/john-anderson-shoots-again-for-charts--19459260 | archive-url=https://archive.today/20130105161014/http://new.music.yahoo.com/tommy-lee/news/john-anderson-shoots-again-for-charts--19459260 | url-status=dead | archive-date=January 5, 2013 | publisher=Yahoo Music | date=April 9, 2007 | access-date=May 9, 2009 }}</ref> and co-wrote Rich's 2009 single "[[Shuttin' Detroit Down]]"<ref>{{cite web | title=John Rich: Nation's Financial Crisis Inspired "Shuttin' Detroit Down" | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1608315/john-rich-nations-financial-crisis-inspired-shuttin-detroit-down.jhtml | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090405125630/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1608315/john-rich-nations-financial-crisis-inspired-shuttin-detroit-down.jhtml | url-status=dead | archive-date=April 5, 2009 | publisher=CMT.com | date=April 1, 2009 | access-date=May 9, 2009}}</ref> He has been named an honorary member of the [[MuzikMafia]], of which Rich is also a member.<ref>{{cite web | title=MuzikMafia members | url=http://www.muzikmafia.com/artists.php | access-date=May 9, 2009 | archive-date=April 7, 2010 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100407082230/http://www.muzikmafia.com/artists.php | url-status=dead }}</ref>

Anderson lives in [[Smithville, Tennessee]], his home for more than 30 years with his wife and two daughters.<ref name=easymoney/>
